body:
Problem: BufModifiedSet autocmd only triggered for current buffer during
redraw, causing delayed events when :wa writes non-current buffers.

Solution: Use Optionset with modified pattern replace.

Fix #32817

sure but weird things happen, and crashes should never happen. also, it would avoid needing to fiddle with `b_locked`, which is basically a hack.
i guess `b_changed_invalid` technically should be set in the deferred handler?
Not sure there's other places that conditionally set `<abuf>` like this. As far as I'm aware, it's either never or always set for a specific event type?

comment_data.body:
Without b_locked, the deferred OptionSet fires between RPC calls at a point where no lock is held, allowing bwipeout! to successfully wipe the terminal buffer and close the channel. The lock ensures the buffer stays alive during autocmd execution, consistent with synchronous OptionSet behavior.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/0864939cc58d3f0af1a88a4baf34ed6b2a2c53ed/test/functional/terminal/buffer_spec.lua#L1365-L1378
Modify the test to call `nvim_open_term` and delete the autocmd in a single event, like via exec_lua. (don't remove its E937 check)
Restore the E937 check

comment_regular_data.body:
With this PR, the following will lead to a heap-use-after-free:
```vim
file Xa
call setline(1, 'foo')
autocmd BufModifiedSet * bwipe!
write
```

Not a result of this PR, but looks like the `'charconvert'` evaluation in `buf_write` may cause a similar crash to that:

```vim
set charconvert=execute('%bw!')
write ++enc=lmao boom
```
After thinking about `eval_charconvert`, maybe `buf_write` needs to add b_locked to prevent the buffer from being deleted while writing.  will try it out  in another PR

> Solution: Trigger BufModifiedSet immediately in buf_write() when any buffer's modified status changes, using proper autocommand context.

Does this mean we can drop the other cases where `apply_autocmds(EVENT_BUFMODIFIEDSET` is called? After this PR there will be 3 of them.

Honestly the implementation of `BufModifiedSet` was really sloppy. I am just noticing `buf->b_changed_invalid` which seems like a fragile hack. Not to mention the overlap with `OptionSet`, and the fact that this `BufModifiedSet` event doesn't even fire for numerous, common cases... what is the point of it? Can we drop it and make `OptionSet modified` work instead?
just gave it a try and it seems to work as expected ü§î

I suppose a concern with a _sometimes_ deferred event like this is that the observed event order may be confusing.

For example, if `:set modified` runs after a deferred `OptionSet modified` that wasn't yet applied:

```vim
au OptionSet modified echom !!v:option_old '->' !!v:option_new '- actual:' &modified
new /tmp/foo
call setline(1, 'hi')
write
set modified
```

You can get out-of-order events like this:

```
0 -> 1 - actual: 1
0 -> 1 - actual: 1
1 -> 0 - actual: 1 (plus, !!v:option_new differs from &modified)
```

Dunno if it's worth worrying about or documenting. While not a cure, maybe it'd help to only fire the deferred OptionSet if `&modified` still equals the `v:option_new` from when it was queued? Or maybe defer all `OptionSet modified`? Meh.

(Or to maybe process the queue first when about to _actually_ apply an autocmd? Eh, that might be weird... depending on the event it may be an unideal time, like when locks are set?)

seem like `aucmd_prepbuf(&aco, buf)` creates a temporary window, which causes some float_spec tests to fail.
However, if we don‚Äôt do this, when `OptionSet modified` is triggered, we can‚Äôt determine which buffer caused the event. So can this be handled as a special case by explicitly setting `abuf` instead and document in doc ü§î

about order the guard drops events in the `:wa` case, and flushing the queue before autocmds risks firing at unsafe times..  idk üòÆ‚Äçüí®

Sounds like the autocommand window. Is it not possible to fix the test? Anyway, I'll _defer_ (heh) opinions on setting `<abuf>` to someone else.

> flushing the queue before autocommands risks firing at unsafe times

Generally it shouldn't be unsafe, as any restrictions would be inherited. (would need to be careful that stuff like `<abuf>` is validated before calling the originally intended event though) If it's still unsafe after that, then that implies it was unsafe to trigger any autocommand there, which would be a bug. I still don't like the idea, though.

@seandewar  previous implementation was missing a condition check, which caused some failures in float_spec. when using `aucmd_prepbuf`,  now it works fine and no need to set abuf, it  works like doc mentioned. the execution order looks correct now, at least from what I can see. I also added a test for it. How does it look to you now ü§î
